column1: What is React Native?
column2: React Native is a framework for building native mobile apps using React. It compiles JavaScript to native components for iOS and Android.

column1: How is React Native different from React?
column2: React targets the web DOM, while React Native targets mobile native views. Instead of <div>, <span>, etc., it uses components like <View> and <Text>.

column1: What are core components in React Native?
column2: Some common core components are: View, Text, Image, TextInput, ScrollView, FlatList, TouchableOpacity.

column1: How does styling work in React Native?
column2: React Native uses JavaScript objects for styling via the StyleSheet API, similar to inline CSS but with camelCased properties.

column1: How does navigation work in React Native?
column2: Use the react-navigation library for stack, tab, and drawer navigation using navigators like createStackNavigator and createBottomTabNavigator.

column1: How do you access device features in React Native?
column2: Use libraries like react-native-camera, react-native-geolocation, or APIs from Expo (if using Expo).

column1: What is Expo and how does it differ from plain React Native?
column2: Expo is a set of tools for building RN apps faster. It abstracts native modules, making setup easier, but limits customization unless ejected.

column1: How do you handle API calls in React Native?
column2: Same as React: use fetch or axios inside useEffect. Handle loading, error, and response states.

column1: How do you test a React Native app?
column2: Use Jest for unit tests, React Native Testing Library for components, and Detox or Appium for end-to-end testing.

column1: What is the difference between controlled and uncontrolled components in React Native?
column2: Controlled components have their value controlled by React state, while uncontrolled ones rely on refs or internal state (e.g., TextInput).

column1: How do you work with images in React Native?
column2: Use the <Image> component. Source can be static (require) or dynamic (URI). Use resizeMode for layout control.

column1: What is FlatList and when should you use it?
column2: FlatList efficiently renders large scrollable lists. It supports lazy loading and recycling of views for better performance.

column1: How does gesture handling work in React Native?
column2: Use react-native-gesture-handler for complex gestures, or Touchable components for simple taps.

column1: How do you manage global state in React Native?
column2: Use Context + useReducer, Redux Toolkit, Recoil, Zustand, or Jotai depending on complexity.

column1: How do you handle authentication in React Native?
column2: Use secure storage (like react-native-keychain or expo-secure-store), and libraries like Firebase Auth, Auth0, or custom JWT logic.

column1: How do you implement navigation guards or conditional navigation?
column2: Use listeners like 'beforeRemove' or conditionally navigate inside useEffect based on auth state or logic.

column1: How does hot reloading work in React Native?
column2: Hot reloading updates changed code without losing state. Fast Refresh is the modern version of hot reload in RN.

column1: What is the difference between View and SafeAreaView?
column2: SafeAreaView ensures content doesn't overlap notches or status bars on iOS. Use it as the root view when needed.

column1: How do you store data locally in React Native?
column2: Use AsyncStorage (deprecated), @react-native-async-storage/async-storage, or MMKV for encrypted, fast local storage.

column1: How do you handle network errors and offline state?
column2: Use NetInfo to monitor connectivity and conditionally show offline messages or queue requests.

column1: How do you make the UI responsive across different screen sizes?
column2: Use Flexbox layout, Dimensions API, PixelRatio, or utility libraries like react-native-responsive-dimensions.

column1: How do you implement push notifications?
column2: Use services like Firebase Cloud Messaging (FCM) with react-native-push-notification or Expo Notifications.

column1: How do you upload files or images in React Native?
column2: Use react-native-image-picker or Expo ImagePicker, then upload via fetch/axios with FormData.

column1: What are native modules and how do you use them?
column2: Native modules are platform-specific code (Java/Obj-C) exposed to JS. Use them via NativeModules or create custom ones.

column1: What are the benefits of using TypeScript in React Native?
column2: TypeScript improves type safety, editor support, and refactoring. It prevents common bugs and improves maintainability.

column1: How do you mock native modules in tests?
column2: Use Jest mocks and __mocks__ directory. Mock APIs from native modules (e.g., react-native-device-info) manually or with jest.mock.

column1: What is Metro bundler?
column2: Metro is the default JS bundler for React Native. It handles module resolution, transpiling, and live reloading.

column1: What are common performance optimizations in React Native?
column2: Use FlatList correctly, avoid inline functions, useMemo, memo, optimize image sizes, and batch state updates.

column1: What is bridging in React Native?
column2: Bridging connects JavaScript and native code. It allows JS to call native modules and vice versa.

column1: How do you publish a React Native app to App Store and Google Play?
column2: Build a release version (Xcode or Gradle), create store listings, sign the app, and upload via Transporter or Play Console.

column1: What is CodePush and how do you integrate it with React Native?
column2: CodePush is a service for over-the-air JS bundle updates. Integrate via the react-native-code-push plugin and configure release keys in your app.

column1: How do you set up deep linking in React Native apps?
column2: Configure URL schemes (iOS) and intent filters (Android), and use React Navigationâ€™s linking prop to map incoming URLs to screens.

column1: What are headless JS tasks and when are they used?
column2: Headless JS allows running background tasks on Android without UI, useful for handling push notifications or background fetch.

column1: How do you implement animations in React Native?
column2: Use the Animated API for declarative animations or libraries like Reanimated for performance-critical use cases.

column1: What is the difference between the Animated API and Reanimated?
column2: Animated runs animations on the JS thread; Reanimated runs animations on the UI thread via JSI for improved performance.

column1: How do you handle accessibility in React Native?
column2: Use accessibilityLabel, accessibilityRole, and accessibilityHint props, and test with screen readers.

column1: How do you integrate push notifications with FCM or APNs?
column2: Use libraries like react-native-firebase or react-native-push-notification to register devices, retrieve tokens, and handle notification events.

column1: What is Flipper and how do you use it?
column2: Flipper is a mobile app debugger with plugins for logs, network, layout, and database inspection. Enable it in your debug build.

column1: What is the Hermes JavaScript engine and its benefits?
column2: Hermes is a lightweight JS engine optimized for React Native, reducing app size and improving startup performance.

column1: How do you detect app state changes with the AppState API?
column2: Use the AppState module to listen for 'change' events indicating active, background, or inactive states.

column1: How do you optimize image loading in React Native?
column2: Use appropriately sized images, caching solutions like FastImage, and progressive loading placeholders.

column1: What is the difference between PixelRatio and Dimensions APIs?
column2: Dimensions provides screen metrics; PixelRatio offers pixel density information and conversion helpers.

column1: How do you write custom native UI components in React Native?
column2: Implement native code (Java/Obj-C/Swift), export views via UIManager, and wrap them in JS using requireNativeComponent.

column1: What are JSI and TurboModules?
column2: JSI (JavaScript Interface) is a C++ API for invoking the JS runtime; TurboModules use JSI to access native modules directly without the React Bridge.

column1: What is the Fabric architecture in React Native?
column2: Fabric is the new rendering engine that enables synchronous layout, reduces bridge overhead, and improves UI performance.

column1: How do you implement in-app purchases in React Native?
column2: Use libraries like react-native-iap or expo-in-app-purchases to connect to App Store and Play Store billing APIs and handle purchase flows.

column1: How do you structure a large-scale React Native project?
column2: Organize by feature or domain, separate shared components, use a service layer for API/logic, and maintain clear folder structures.

column1: How do you perform A/B testing in React Native?
column2: Use services like Firebase Remote Config or Optimizely SDK to fetch variants and render different UI/components per experiment.

column1: How do you integrate device sensors like accelerometer or gyroscope?
column2: Use libraries like react-native-sensors or Expo Sensors to subscribe to sensor data streams and process readings.

column1: What are best practices for error handling in React Native apps?
column2: Use global error boundaries for JS errors, implement native crash reporting (e.g., Sentry), handle rejected Promises, and provide user-friendly feedback.
